reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This story reminded me of taking my son backing for the first time. I loved the writing and message. Time dust off my pack, bag, and tent! Well done!!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars This book taught me a lot
reviews.reviewText: Over the years I have read more than two dozen books about hiking the Appalachian Trail. This is the first I have read about the Sierras.I love this novel. The storyline is interesting and seems consistent with the other novels but the author added so much history. I am anxious for the day I can hike the trail.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars interesting but wordy
reviews.reviewText: Wonderful and inspiring tale of hiking, but at times very long lectures about early explorers of the sierra. At the same time the main protagonist is telling his friend not to lecture you will want to tell the author the same. Also an annoying substitution of “woulda” and coulda” in the text for would have and could have. This would have been okay in dialog but it disrupts the text. Would benefit from better editing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Taking a trip back in time
reviews.reviewText: Having hiked parts of the John Muir trail myself I was totally engrossed in this story. So much descriptive detail that I felt like I was there again. It was such an excellent read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Feel good Adventure story
reviews.reviewText: I always look for feel good stories to read at bedtime. This was a fun adventure story with some coming of age elements and a cool seeing that kept me interested throughout.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Enjoyable story, somewhat irritating book
reviews.reviewText: Let me start by saying I enjoyed this story. Largely because I wanted to be there. I wanted to be on the trail with Gil and Syd. I wanted to see what they saw, experience the events they experienced. And it's a compelling story - two individuals, each with their own personal issues, fears, dreams, coming together in an unexpected friendship, learning and growing from their experience in nature, and essentially "saving" each other. It's a great story, and deserves to be told greatly.However, seemed to me like the author was trying to accomplish too many things in one book. First there is all the stuff about the history of the John Muir Trail and the Sierra Nevada. Very convenient that Syd is a retired college professor who knows more about the history of the trail than any park ranger, and is more than willing to share every detail. He also seems to be able to quote more lines from various poems and books than I will ever remember. His lectures got a little tiresome, and Gil was more than willing to keep them going. At times their conversations seemed very scripted, like Gil was a 5th grader who had an assignment to interview a park ranger about the trail's history. His questions sounded very rehearsed. Real people don't talk like this.Then we had the social commentary on all kinds of issues - education, climate change, food production, trail etiquette... Every so often it was if one or more of the characters felt the need to pontificate about one thing or another. Don't get me wrong - I pretty much agreed with everything they said - this isn't a political disagreement kind of thing. But again it felt like I was being lectured to, and the lectures didn't come naturally. You knew when you read the first sentence that you were in for another two page rant about something. A little bit, okay, but let's not try to cover every social issue, and let's not do it in a way that seems so scripted and forced.My problem with these is that they detracted from the story. No offense to the author, but I just feel that the story itself would have been more impactful if we hadn't been beat over the head with extraneous information and opinions.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A great story
reviews.reviewText: This is well written with a balance of human relationships, philosophy on life and hiking information. Nicely done and highly recommended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Very Enjoyable Read
reviews.reviewText: I’ve done a bit of backpacking and found this book true to my own experience. I’ve also studied a bit of Asian philosophy so the comparisons along the trail of letting go of the great rat race and experiencing life moment by moment rang true. But my probably poor understanding of the Tao is that a true seeker always experiences, at some point in their quest, Nothingness and that’s one of the high points of the philosophy because it also contains the opposite bit as well, Everything. I’m surprised that an Asian philosophy professor didn’t recognize this. But overall an excellent read. I loved the smattering of Asian poetry throughout and the lovely thoughtful moments along the trail. Makes me want to hike the JMT (John Muir Trail).

This novel is quite out of the ordinary- well written but with philosophical overtones that the writer uses with his Uncle Syd- You will either be completely absorbed in the story or not depending on your view of the extraordinary- hard to stop reading such a heartfelt saga-Bravo to the author

Vor fast zwanzig Jahren bin ich den JMT auch gewandert und viele Beschreibungen in diesem Buch haben meine Erinnerungen wach gerufen und es war, als ob ich erst gestern dort gewesen war. An manchen Stellen war mir das rumphilosophieren ein wenig zu dick aufgetragen, aber dennoch konnte ich das Buch nicht weglegen…. Und ich hatte damals denselben Mantra-Song im Kopf wie der Autor. speziell auf dem Golden Staircase.Was mich allerdings erschreckt hat war, wieviele Leute der Autor auf dem Trail getroffen hat. Vor 20 Jahren war definitiv weniger los gewesen und das war gut so.Ein tolles Buch für jeden, der den JMT schon selbst erlebt und und jeden, der ihn noch erwandern will!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 6, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The story was beautifully written and took the reader on their own journey. The same journey we all share "life".=

reviews.reviewTitle: This book is a wake up call.
reviews.reviewText: There’s a lot in this book. There’s the angst of youth, the fear of death and all the life in between. Partly a great coming of age book, a study on looking at your demise, a travelogue and a philosophy book. I live it

I doubt that the 2 hikers made 400 km in 4 weeks - too little supplies with them. You need 2500-3000 kcal/day minimum. Too much philosophies - not all readers are interested in Tennysons poems and likewise .Finally I mourn with the mule that was left to die just because it was stubborn - I will not buy this author again.
